gr.forth.ics.graph.path
Class Traverser

java.lang.Object
  gr.forth.ics.graph.path.Traverser

public class Traverser
extends Object

A utility that simplifies executing graph traversals. A traversal may be executed in a depth-first or breadth-first fashion, while it can also be configured not to visit twice the same node or the same edge. A traversal is modelled as an iterator of Path instances, representing the various discovered paths of the graph. The direction of the traversal is also configured (see {traverse(InspectableGraph, Node, Direction)), so the traversal may flow towards the direction of the discovered edges (Direction.OUT), oppositely (Direction.IN) or either way (Direction.EITHER).

This example prints all paths that discover a new node in a graph: InspectableGraph graph = ...; Traverser traverser = Traverser.newDfs().withoutRepeatingNodes().build(); for (Path path : traverser.traverse(graph, graph.aNode(), Direction.OUT)) { System.out.println(path); }

This (slow by nature) example collects all directed paths of a graph: InspectableGraph graph = ...; //should be a dag, or else the paths are infinite Traverser traverser = Traverser.newDfs().build(); Set<Path> paths = new HashSet<Path>(); for (Node n : graph.nodes()) { PathIterator iterator = traverser.traverse(graph, n, Direction.OUT).iterator(); while (iterator.hasNext()) { Path path = iterator.next(); if (paths.contains(path)) { iterator.skipExplorationOfLastPath(); //discontinue the exploration of already visited path } else { paths.add(path); } } }

Method Detail

traverse

public Traverser.PathIterable traverse(InspectableGraph graph,
                                       Node startNode,
                                       Direction direction)
Initiates a traversal of the specified graph, starting with the given node (which must be contained in the graph) and returns a Traverser.PathIterable that returns the explored paths in a step-by-step fashion. A traversal starts at a node and tries to expand, via incident edges, as much as possible. The traversal consider only edges that are incident to already discovered nodes, and have compatible direction to the direction parameter given. For example, if node A has been discovered via some path, it may lead to the discovery of node B if
  • there is an edge {A-->B} and direction was set to Direction.OUT or Direction.EITHER, or
  • there is an edge {B-->A} and direction was set to Direction.IN or Direction.EITHER

The return iterators do not support Iterator.remove() method.

Parameters:
graph - the graph on which to perform the traversal
startNode - the node to start the traversal
direction - defines the direction that edges must have in order to be considered when expanding already explored paths
Returns:
a PathIterable that gives access to the paths discovered by the traversal

newDfs

public static Traverser.TraverserBuilder newDfs()
Specifies that depth-first-search will be used for the traversal of a graph, and returns a builder to further configure that traversal.

Returns:
a TraverserBuilder, to further configure the traversal

newBfs

public static Traverser.TraverserBuilder newBfs()
Specifies that breadth-first-search will be used for the traversal of a graph, and returns a builder to further configure that traversal.

Returns:
a TraverserBuilder, to further configure the traversal

newCustom

public static Traverser.TraverserBuilder newCustom(Comparator<? super Path> pathComparator)
Specifies that the traversal will visit the discovered paths using a priority queue with the given path comparator, and returns a builder to further configure that traversal. At every step, when the traversal has many unexplored paths from which to choose the next one to explore, the minimum (as defined by the comparator) will be used.

Returns:
a TraverserBuilder, to further configure the traversal
